newsitem.title: THAILAND: Thai stocks close higher despite S&P downgrade.
newsitem.headline: Thai stocks close higher despite S&P downgrade.

text.p: Thai stocks ended up on Tuesday as investors shrugged off Standard and Poor's downgrade of two major commerical banks and snapped up cheap blue-chip shares, brokers said.
After dipping around midday, the SET index ended up 6.95 points to 693.87 on 2.8 billion baht turnover. The SET-50 rose 0.78 points to 51.19.

"The market appeared not to have much negative reaction on S&P's downgrade of two commercial banks. Most share prices were already cheap after the recent fall," said one broker at Wall Street Finance.
Brokers said an S&P affirmation of Thailand's credit rating might also have helped boost investor confidence in the economy and the government's economic policies.
S&P on Tuesday downgraded the credit ratings of Thai Farmers Bank and Siam Commercial Bank Plc to BBB-plus/A2 from A-minus/A2.
It also affirmed Thailand's single-A long term and A-1 short term foreign currency debt ratings, reflecting the government's substantial financial flexibility.
"S&P's affirmation of the country's rating is quite good news. It reflects some degree of confidence in the government's newly-announced economic policies," said another broker at Ekkapat Finance.
Thai Farmers dropped one baht to close at 116 on the most active turnover of 327 million baht.
Siam Commercial ended unchanged at 132 and Krung Thai Bank gained 0.75 to 35.50.
General Finance, which denied reports that it planned to merge with a finance company, finished unchanged at 18.50 baht. -- Anuchit Nguyen (662) 652-0642
